question: A linked list is a collection of nodes where each node contains data and a ________ to the next node.
Unlike arrays, linked lists use ________ memory allocation, allowing dynamic resizing.
The last node in a singly linked list points to ________.
A node in a linked list consists of data and a ________ to the next node.
The first node of a linked list is called the ________ node.
In C, memory for a new linked list node is allocated using the ________ function.
In a linked list, inserting a node at the beginning requires modifying the ________ pointer.
The time complexity for inserting a node at the beginning of a linked list is ________.
A ________ linked list allows traversal in both directions.
A circular linked list's last node points to the ________ node.
In a singly linked list, each node has ________ pointer(s).
In a doubly linked list, each node has ________ pointers.
To delete a node in a linked list, you must modify the ________ pointer of the previous node.
The ________ function in C is used to release memory allocated to a linked list node.
In a circular linked list, the last nodeâ€™s pointer is set to the ________ node.
A linked list where the last node connects to the first node is called a ________ linked list.
The process of visiting each node in a linked list is called ________.
The head pointer in a linked list stores the address of the ________ node.
The main advantage of linked lists over arrays is ________ memory allocation.
To insert a node after a given node in a linked list, modify the ________ pointer of the given node.
